results.title: Managing currencies (NP)
results.creator_credit: Craig Saunders, Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Monash University, Open Learning Agency of Australia and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “The Global Economy”.
The value of currency exchange rates has a crucial role in a nation’s economy, affecting the rate of import and export, as well as the rate of unemployment and inflation. In this episode of the Open Learning Economics course we study the ways in which governments can intervene in fixing a value to their currency. The first part of the episode we look at the economic crisis precipitated by a strong US dollar in the 1980s. President Ronald Reagan’s committment to laissez-faire economics meant that the German Deutschmark and the Japanese Yen consistently traded more effectively against the US dollar, resulting in loss of production and increasing unemployment in the United States. A panel of economists analyse the effectiveness of the Plaza Accord, initiated by Ronald Reagan and James Baker in the late 1980s, to reverse some of the imbalances of a free-floating exchange rate. In the second example, we look at the attempt of the Thatcher government in Great Britain to fix the exchange rate of the pound, in an attempt to curtail spiralling inflation and unemployment.

results.title: Managing creatively
results.creator_credit: David Evans, Millbank Films and Ron Tanner
results.brief_description: Tells the story of a manager whose creativity is stifled at work. Shows how he crosses the barriers which block his creativity and how he finds he can release his own ideas and the ideas of others for productive work.

results.title: Managing change
results.creator_credit: David Evans, Millbank Films and Peter Rawson
results.brief_description: Follows the disruption created in a factory when a change in methods is not properly explained to the workers. This dramatisation graphically shows how overworked staff and poor communication causes dissatisfaction and interrupts production.

results.title: Managing aggressive behaviour
results.creator_credit: Tim Abbott, Helen Edwards, Tony Shaddock and New England Educational Diagnostic Centre
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Managing difficult behaviours”.
Module 3.1. Designed to assist the intellectual disability residential care worker to understand why aggressive behaviour occurs, learn how to “get in first” to avoid aggressive outbursts and how to deal systematically with particular forms of aggressive behaviour that have become a regular behaviour pattern. Accompanied by 48p. in-service training manual.

results.title: Managing a play
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds and Maurice Gnesin
results.brief_description: Importance of publicity and ticket management for successful play production shown in detailed study of publicity director and manager’s responsibilities. Film includes preparations of newspaper advertisements, releases, posters and handbills as well as advance ticket selling, box-office procedures and ticket counting.
results.creator_credit_for_label: International Film Bureau, Robert Edmonds, Betty Edmonds and Maurice Gnesin

results.title: Managers can avoid wasting time
results.creator_credit: WGBH Educational Foundation and Ashton Peery
results.brief_description: Schaffer’s Breakthrough Concept in action at the Morgan Guaranty Bank is used as a model to present a four fold strategy to increase management productivity by organising both time and resources effectively to meet the demands of anxiety-producing problems and mobilise more time for priority tasks.

results.title: Management: the bottom line (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “Everybody’s business: management in action (NP)”.
Management must strive to achieve many outcomes. They are responsible to the organisation, the staff, the customer and society. Productivity improvement is their primary responsibility. However, this must be considered relative to the needs and wants of all the stakeholders. Meeting the needs and desires of all these people is often a very complex balancing act. How well it is carried out is a measure of the managers. This episode is likely to be a full scale debate among Australian managers, unionists, commentators, and employees about the role of management in the 1990’s.

results.title: Management: a fundamental question (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Everybody’s business: management in action (NP)”.
This episode asks the complex question: what is management? Since there are many diverse management systems, this episode follows a day in the life of two very different managers - Tricia Caswell, Director of the Australian Conservation Foundation and Michael Bowman from Ford Australia. The Chief Executive Officer of the City of Melbourne, Elizabeth Proust, joins Kerry O’Brien in the studio.
